channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: In Supreme Court Immunity Decision, Clashing Views of the Nature of Politics
item.description: The Supreme Court’s conservative majority largely embraced Donald Trump’s dark view of tit-for-tat partisan prosecutions while liberals cited the prospect of power unchecked by legal accountability.

item.title: Jay Slater’s Disappearance on Tenerife Spurs Online Sleuths and Speculation
item.description: Jay Slater disappeared on the Spanish island of Tenerife last month. His whereabouts sparked intense online speculation.

item.title: Paramount merger with Skydance back on under new terms following collapse of talks
item.description: National Amusements, the family company that controls Paramount, will refer the deal to a special committee of Paramount directors for review.

item.title: You See a Hedge. He Sees Something Else.
item.description: Tim Bushe decided to shape the hedges in his London neighborhood into a menagerie. They’ve become a local attraction.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Top U.S. Official to Hold Talks in Paris on Defusing Israel-Hezbollah Conflict
item.description: Amos Hochstein’s trip to France comes after comments by Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken that Israel had “effectively lost sovereignty” near the border with Lebanon because of attacks by Hezbollah.

item.title: The ECB’s chief is tired of people blaming Taylor Swift for the Eurozone’s sticky inflation
item.description: “It’s not just Taylor Swift, you know,” Christine Lagarde told the ECB Forum. “Others have come as well.”

item.title: Kings Battle for an Ancient Throne in Nigeria
item.description: Two men claim to be the emir of Kano, an ancient kingdom in northern Nigeria. Their struggle for power and influence is feeding into a wider competition ahead of the country’s next election.

item.title: You See a Hedge. He Sees Something Else.
item.description: Tim Bushe decided to shape the hedges in his London neighborhood into a menagerie. They’ve become a local attraction.

item.title: Even the Pentagon can’t completely freeze Huawei out of its operations
item.description: As it has done since the law was passed more than five years ago, the Pentagon is seeking a formal waiver to its obligations under Section 889 of the 2019 National Defense Authorization Act.

item.title: How to Handle Crowded Airports and Roads This Fourth of July
item.description: As record crowds hit the roads and the skies this week for the holiday, here’s what to know before traveling.

item.title: Kings Battle for an Ancient Throne in Nigeria
item.description: Two men claim to be the emir of Kano, an ancient kingdom in northern Nigeria. Their struggle for power and influence is feeding into a wider competition ahead of the country’s next election.

item.title: The German railway system has become a ‘national embarrassment’ amid Euro 2024—and there seems to be no light at the end of the tunnel
item.description: German punctuality is well-known—but its railway service managed by Deutsche Bahn has struggled to follow it, hampering the fan experience at Euros 2024.

item.title: One Painful Debate Is Not Evidence of America’s Decline
item.description: Russia and China have seized on last week’s painful presidential debate to push their narrative that America is in terminal decline.

item.title: An Uproar Over a Chinese Doping Case, Except in China
item.description: Chinese state news and social media has been virtually silent about 23 swimmers secretly testing positive in 2021, even as the issue is being debated widely abroad, including in Congress.

item.title: Arise will pay $7 million to workers FTC says the gig company misled about how much money they could make on its platform
item.description: “Arise lured in workers with false promises about what they could earn while requiring them to pay out-of-pocket for essential equipment, training, and other expenses,” FTC Chairwoman Lina Khan said.
